validation_metadata.verification_method: Direct review of Texas Government Code Chapter 552

rights_of_access.description: All government information is presumed to be available to the public unless specifically excepted from disclosure. The burden is on the governmental body to demonstrate that an exception applies, not on the requester to prove a right to access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Information must be in custody or control of governmental body; exceptions must be specifically demonstrated
rights_of_access.applies_to: All information held by Texas governmental bodies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This establishes Texas's strong presumption of openness and places burden of proof on agencies
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.002, this information is presumed public unless you can demonstrate a specific exception applies.'

rights_of_access.description: Governmental bodies must promptly produce public information for inspection, duplication, or both, within 10 business days after receiving a written request. If additional time is needed, the body must provide a written statement detailing when the information will be available.
rights_of_access.conditions: 10 business days from receipt of written request; extensions require written notice with specific date
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Texas Public Information Act requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Business days are Monday-Friday excluding state holidays; clock starts when request received
rights_of_access.request_tips: State: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.221(a) requires you to respond within 10 business days or provide written statement of when information will be available.'

rights_of_access.description: If a governmental body cannot produce information within 10 business days, it must certify when and why additional time is needed. The additional time may not exceed a reasonable period given the request.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be certified in writing; must state specific date when information will be available; timeframe must be reasonable
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests requiring more than 10 business days to fulfill
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: What is 'reasonable' depends on volume, complexity, and agency resources; excessive delays can be challenged
rights_of_access.request_tips: If delayed: 'Please certify under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.221(b) why additional time is needed and provide specific availability date.'

rights_of_access.description: If a governmental body fails to respond or provide information within required timeframes, the requester may seek an opinion from the Attorney General. Unreasonable delay can be treated as denial triggering AG review.
rights_of_access.conditions: Deadline must have passed; proper request must have been submitted; no response or unreasonable delay
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests where deadlines missed or delays unreasonable
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: AG opinion process provides administrative remedy before litigation
rights_of_access.request_tips: After deadline: 'Your failure to timely respond under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.221 allows me to seek Attorney General opinion under § 552.301.'

rights_of_access.description: Governmental bodies must waive fees if releasing the information primarily benefits the general public. Public benefit is presumed when information is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of government operations.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must demonstrate primary benefit to general public; not for private commercial interest
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests where disclosure serves public interest
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Journalistic, academic, and public interest requests often qualify for fee waivers
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request waiver: 'Please waive fees under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.267 as this information primarily benefits the general public by [explain public benefit].'

rights_of_access.description: Governmental bodies must waive or reduce fees for requesters who are indigent and unable to pay. Indigence may be established through provision of evidence of receipt of government assistance or other means.
rights_of_access.conditions: Requester must provide evidence of indigence (e.g., government assistance receipt, income documentation)
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requesters who cannot afford fees due to financial hardship
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This ensures access is not denied solely due to inability to pay
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'I request fee waiver under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.267(c) based on indigence. [Provide evidence of government assistance or income documentation].'

rights_of_access.description: Charges for copies must be limited to actual costs of reproducing the information. Labor costs may only be charged if request exceeds $40 in materials costs. The first 50 pages of paper records are free for standard requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must itemize charges; labor costs only if materials exceed $40; first 50 pages free
rights_of_access.applies_to: All requests for copies of public information
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Standard paper copies typically 10 cents per page; electronic copies often minimal or free
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge fees: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.261 limits charges to actual costs. Please provide itemized fee estimate. Note first 50 pages must be provided free.'

rights_of_access.description: If information exists in electronic format, requesters may request it be provided electronically. Governmental bodies must provide information in electronic format when requested unless providing in that format is not feasible.
rights_of_access.conditions: Information must exist in electronic format; electronic delivery must be feasible
rights_of_access.applies_to: Information maintained electronically
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Electronic delivery often reduces costs and expedites access
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please provide this information in electronic format under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.228, preferably via email as [PDF/Excel/etc.].'

rights_of_access.description: Certain categories of frequently requested information must be posted on governmental body's website, making them immediately accessible without formal request. This includes meeting agendas, budgets, salary information, and other commonly sought records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to specified categories of information; must be posted in accessible format
rights_of_access.applies_to: Frequently requested categories of public information (budgets, salaries, contracts, etc.)
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Check agency website first - many records may already be posted online
rights_of_access.request_tips: Reference posting requirement: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.233 requires this information be posted online. If not posted, please explain why and provide immediately.'

rights_of_access.description: If only portions of information are excepted from disclosure, governmental bodies must provide access to the remaining portions after redacting the excepted information. Partial exceptions do not justify withholding entire documents.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must redact only what is specifically excepted; must provide all non-excepted portions
rights_of_access.applies_to: Records containing both public and excepted information
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must perform careful redaction analysis rather than categorical withholding
rights_of_access.request_tips: Demand: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.008 requires you to provide all non-excepted portions after redacting excepted information. Please perform segregability analysis.'

rights_of_access.description: When a governmental body withholds information, it must seek an opinion from the Attorney General. Requesters receive notice and may submit comments. The AG's decision can be appealed to court, providing robust administrative and judicial review.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must submit withholding request to AG within 10 business days; requester may submit comments; AG must rule within reasonable time
rights_of_access.applies_to: All information governmental bodies seek to withhold
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This unique Texas process provides third-party review of withholding decisions before litigation
rights_of_access.request_tips: Monitor AG process: 'Under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.301, you must submit withholding request to AG. Please notify me so I may submit comments.'

rights_of_access.description: Either the requester or the governmental body may appeal the Attorney General's decision to district court. The court reviews the AG's decision and the underlying withholding decision de novo.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must file suit within specific timeframes; court reviews AG decision and underlying records
rights_of_access.applies_to: AG opinions regarding disclosure or withholding
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: De novo review means court makes independent determination, not just reviewing AG for error
rights_of_access.request_tips: If AG rules against you: 'I may appeal this AG opinion to district court under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.324 for de novo review.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters may file suit to compel production of public information wrongfully withheld. Courts may award attorney fees and costs to prevailing requesters. Suits must be filed in Travis County or the county where the governmental body's principal offices are located.
rights_of_access.conditions: Information must have been wrongfully withheld; requester must substantially prevail
rights_of_access.applies_to: Information improperly denied or withheld
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Attorney fee recovery makes litigation financially viable for requesters with valid claims
rights_of_access.request_tips: For litigation: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.321 authorizes mandamus action to compel production and recover attorney fees if I prevail.'

rights_of_access.description: Public officials who willfully or intentionally violate the Public Information Act, including destroying records after receiving a request, may face criminal penalties. This deters deliberate obstruction of access.
rights_of_access.conditions: Violation must be willful or intentional; includes destroying records to avoid disclosure
rights_of_access.applies_to: Governmental employees who intentionally violate the Act
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: While rarely prosecuted, this provision emphasizes seriousness of PIA compliance
rights_of_access.request_tips: In cases of suspected bad faith: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.353 provides criminal penalties for willful violations, including record destruction after request received.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters are not required to provide identification or state the purpose of their request. Agencies may request contact information only for purposes of responding to the request.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency may request contact info for response purposes but cannot require ID or purpose as condition of access
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public information requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This protects requester privacy and prevents discrimination based on identity or purpose
rights_of_access.request_tips: If asked for ID/purpose: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.222 does not require me to identify myself or state my purpose beyond providing contact information for your response.'

rights_of_access.description: The Public Information Act grants access to 'each person' without regard to residency, citizenship, or connection to Texas. Out-of-state and international requesters have equal rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: None - right extends to all persons regardless of residency
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public information requests to Texas governmental bodies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Courts have rejected agency attempts to limit access based on residency
rights_of_access.request_tips: If residency questioned: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.002 grants each person access to public information without residency requirement.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters have the right to inspect public information before deciding whether to request copies. Inspection allows review without incurring copying costs.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be during regular business hours; agency may supervise to protect records
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public information available for access
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Inspection is particularly useful for voluminous records where only portions may be relevant
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'I wish to inspect this information before requesting copies, as permitted by Tex. Gov't Code § 552.221.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters may request access to data in electronic databases, including requesting extraction of specific data elements or custom queries of existing databases. Agencies may charge actual costs of programming.
rights_of_access.conditions: Database must exist; query must be specific; agency may charge actual programming costs
rights_of_access.applies_to: Structured data maintained in electronic databases
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This allows targeted requests for specific data elements rather than entire databases
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Please extract the following data elements from [database name] under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.231: [specify fields/criteria].'

rights_of_access.description: Public information coordinators and other designated officials must complete training on the Public Information Act. This ensures agencies have knowledgeable staff to handle requests properly.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to public information officers and coordinators; training must be completed within specified timeframes
rights_of_access.applies_to: Agency personnel responsible for PIA compliance
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Well-trained staff improve compliance and reduce delays
rights_of_access.request_tips: If poor handling: 'Has your public information officer completed required training under Tex. Gov't Code § 552.012? Proper training ensures correct handling of requests.'

rights_of_access.description: Each governmental body must designate a public information officer and make the officer's contact information publicly available. This ensures requesters know where to direct requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must designate officer; must publish contact information
rights_of_access.applies_to: All Texas governmental bodies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Contact information should be readily accessible on agency website
rights_of_access.request_tips: If unclear where to submit: 'Tex. Gov't Code § 552.206 requires designation of public information officer. Please provide officer contact information.'
